reviewText:
6.410 - Feesh Proves To Be A Solid 99 Center!

This is another game that takes place inside the world of a micro-organism. You start as a wee little fish and eat your way to the top of the food chain. You will continue to grow and evolve up to 10 times; assuming you avoid the sharks and eat all the puny fish.

This game was originally created in less than 48 hours; while I’m extremely impressed with that; it does show in a few areas. The graphics are well done and pretty unique. The constant white background eliminates some depth of content though. Multiplayer is also just Local so that is basically worthless to someone like me. Online mode would be great.

Overall, for 99 cents you get a pretty enjoyable game that has a plethora of modes to choose from including: Shark Survival, Arcade, Multiplayer and more! It's one of the better paid games you can grab for $1, but not something you specifically need to track down.

Worth $2; only 99 cents though!

reviewText:
Give a man a fish and he'll eat for a day. Give a man Feesh, and he'll eat until he's as big as the petri dish.

Graphics: 10/10. They're basically out of control. This game is the definition of HD.
Gameplay: 8/10. Eating my way to world domination? Yes please.
Audio: 9/10. This is exactly what a petri dish sounds like. The developer clearly did his research.
Name: 11/10. Seriously. It's called Feesh. FEESH. What more can you ask for???
Education: 9/10. I played this game as a replacement for studying for my biology exam. I failed, but I had fun.
Sharks: 1/10. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

So what are you waiting for? BUY THIS GAME. DO IT.

reviewText:
A very fun game, well worth the $.99!
The stylized fish/feesh give it a unique look, and combined with the music, the game can be pretty relaxing!
While each level starts out tough as you struggle to catch the smaller feesh, once you fall into the rhythm, it becomes a lot easier; the final moments before you evolve each time has those tinier feesh practically swimming towards your mouth.
Which can probably work as a metaphor, or something.

reviewText:
Sometimes you just need a game that you can zen out of. For me that just about sums up Terrifying Jellyfish’s debut game, Feesh. The Steam description is particularly well written here because it explains in good detail the point of the game and there really isn’t much more to it than what is already stated there. So instead of going on a long winded post explaining the to’s and about’s the game I’m just going to state how it made me feel.

Meditation isn’t one of my strong points. I’m generally a highly wired individually. Often to my own detriment. I can jump from 0 to 500 in the blink of an eye. Ainslie has tried to help me learn meditation techniques. I generally lack the patience. I can make mountains out of mole hills. I guess this has had a bit to do with my upbringing from the tough western suburbs of Melbourne but also stems from experiences later in life when I suppose you could say I was still a little impressionable. Meditation hasn’t worked as intended. I’ve found that video games can sometimes be an outlet for that – though they can also have the opposite rage inducing effect. Feesh is one of the first games that I’ve come across that really has that zen/meditational effect on me.

There isn’t much to the game. At least not in my experience to it. Its minimalist in a good way. It doesn’t have to offer anything more than what it does. It certainly wont appeal to everyone. Those seeking an epic experience are looking at the wrong game. But for those who can sense the meditative, calming and simpleness of a game such as this and can use it as a timeout then it’s fantastic. The sound, though one sound – it sounds like a kazoo – is rather annoying, the graphics, everything works to achieve this affect for me. I can definitely see myself returning time and again to continue to zen out.

You clever beans Terrifying Jellyfish. Now back to chillout mode.

For similar reviews and our popular daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/
For our Steam group and curation please join us and follow us at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Steamified
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a very marvellous game for being $1. Plus it is a Ludum Dare game so that gets super high respect from me because I have participated in some of those in the past and they are not easy. Anyway, the game is very polished, has a simple but good art style, and enjoyable gameplay. It is comparable to agar.io, but I would say that it is much better. My only complaint would be that I feel that the camera is zoomed in a tad too much at the beginning of each evolution because I always find myself moving along and suddenly being eaten by a slightly larger fish. Maybe that was part of design in order to make the beginning of each evolution even more challenging, I don't really know. There are multiple game modes, which is good too.

Pros:
Simple artwork
Fun, relaxing gameplay
Multiple game modes
Uber respect for Ludum Dare entry as good as this
Underpriced

Cons:
Slightly wonky camera at times
Some REALLY challenging achievements(only if you are into 100%ing games is this a con)

Overall, I would give this game a 7/10. It is small and simple, but what it does it excels at. I would highly suggest this game for its full price, even more perhaps.

reviewText: Cant get past the second evolution. I've tried countless times now, the sharks are far too punishing to make the game fun. I understand having a predator that can eat you and follows you around but dont have 50 of them on 1 level unless its the shark attack mode. Theres no place for that ♥♥♥♥ in arcade or multiplayer. You get to the dashing feesh and the screen is so small that you dash right into a shark and theres NOTHING you can do. Its no longer a game about avoiding larger feesh and trying to eat, its a game about if you are lucky enough not to run into one of the 10+ sharks that are forever hunting you. DONT GET THIS GAME IN ITS CURRENT STATE!\n\nTo the Developer: If you dont plan to reduce the shark number to 2 max at any given point in arcade or multiplayer, then at the very least add an indicator that shows where the sharks are on the edge of the screen. Like a small icon pointing toward them so you dont blindly dash to your death. Both would be great and I would gladly give it another try after that.

reviewText: It's Ok, and a dollar for this might be fair if you just want a cute little abstract arcade game to chill out with.  That said, I have to disagree with reviews that call it amazing in any way.  The fact that it was originally constructed in less than 2 days is an impressive feat, I have to agree, but the economy of action shows.  It needs a lot more love to be really noteworthy.  In particular the game is too easy at this point.  It's fairly sleep inducing it's so easy.  Your first time through, you will likely evolve several times without too much effort.  Figuring out what each critter does to/for you is interesting at first, but the mechanics aren't nearly deep enough to hold one's attention.  Furthermore, the backgrounds are a solid color, and you can't zoom in/out on your own, so you have no sense of scale until you've nearly outgrown the petri shaped dish.  That said, the controller controls were fairly tight and I did enjoy the fact that the developer took obvious care on the controls.\n\nSo, it's neat concept, but don't expect to get a ton of gameplay out of it.

reviewText:
I'll save you some time, go play agar.io instead.

The moment you open the game you will run for the mute button. The title screen music is horrible. The in-game music however is fairly relaxing.

I've given the game a couple tries with friends, and it bugs out every chance it gets. These are not small problems either, they are game stopping. Every game we played we had to restart because the controls would not respond properly, or at all. Player 4 gets booted from the game as soon as it starts. The start menu has no way of exiting, as the exit button doesn't work. Really, it is just not a well made game, save your money.

EDIT: I thought I should add that most of these problems occured during multiplayer. Arcade mode seems to have less problems.This game is however severly lacking without multiplayer.

reviewText:
People seem to rave about the value of this game considering its $0.99. I've played free games that are very minimalist but still fun. At best this is a work in progress.

PRO
- well done on making a game in such a short period of time.

CONS
- little replay value
- small playable area
- chill out mode is pointless
- arcade mode progression is not rewarding (you 'evlolve' and have to start again. if you die you start all the way back fromt the start again).

Overall no price is right for this game.

reviewText:
Thus far I'm going to have to say that this is a fine game with a premise I've always enjoyed:  Eat stuff smaller than you to get bigger, don't get eaten by stuff bigger than you.

However, the controls are absolute crap and there seems to be no options regarding music/sound, which is a bit loud.  I'm writing this after a fairly short amount of time with the game, and it's still a new release, so changes are entirely possible, and changes to this review would certainly follow suit.

And hey, it's only a dollar.  Giving this a tentative recommend and hoping for a patch or two.

Edit:  The developer has promised to add volume controls in an update.

reviewText: Well, it only took me playing the game for a hour and a half straight to get a score of over 1 million and be on top of the leaderboards. Was it worth it? Probablly not. Was it fun? Fairly. Will I do it again? Yup, as soon as I see someone has beat my score. The game is quite entertaining for only $1 so I don't really see the point in not buying it especially if you like the first stage of Spore or like Agar.io. It's not the most revolutionary game out there but it is a fun little time killer. The one downside I have seen? The multiplayer kinda sucks. It starts and someone gets a little bigger than the other player/players and wrecks face then it is over. It only lasts about 1 to 2 min. If that got changed than I would 100% recommend this game for $1. Pick up the game if you want something to do for a little while or to play every now and then. I don't think it will hold you for to long though. If you are looking for a game to play all day this probablly isn't it. I rate it 8/10
